group.name: Hiking and Trail Running trips from NYC  (www.RawTrail.com)

results.description:
DAYLIGHT SAVINGS TIME HAS ENDED. SET CLOCKS BACK ONE HOUR. This is a different hike than the two previously posted. It will be a moderately paced [masked]) mph. The leader will hike westbound for about 2 hours and make a u-turn. Beginners with plenty of energy, new hikers, old timers, anyone interested in a hike filled with fall scenery with uphill/downhill hiking, accessible by public transportation, only 111 minutes from Grand Central via the Harlem Line MetroNorth train, come join us. Bring lunch, dress for the weather and comfortable footwear. Don't forget water, at least two quarts.

Rain or the threat of rain will postpone the hike for a few weeks.

Public Transportation: Grand Central Station, leaving at 7:50 a.m. take the Harlem Line MetroNorth train to the Appalachian Trail stop. You may also pick up the train at other MetroNorth stations. Consult a train schedule. Arrive at the Appalachian Trail train stop at 9:49 a.m. Return time will be at 2:47 pm at the MetroNorth station on the AT. Arrive back at Grand Central at around 5 p.m. Those wishing to stay longer and hike more have the option of catching the 4:47 pm train back to NYC. No shuttling needed. Everyone taking the train will be accommodated.

Driving Directions: Take I-684 from White Plains in Westchester, northbound until you reach the end, about 30 miles. Continue straight (north) on Route 22 north for another 15 miles to Pawling. Then continue on Route 22 north for another 3 miles until you see the Appalachian Trail sign and large parking areas on the left and right sides of the road. Arrive there at 9:30 a.m. The MetroNorth train station is nearby and hidden from the road. We'll walk there and greet the train.

Hike Leader: Steve Galla.  Text[masked]-2222. Inclement weather will postpone the hike. Stay in touch.
results.name: Hike the Appalachian Trail Westbound in Dutchess Co. 7 miles

Let's head out for a MidPackers Long, Slow Distance (MPLSD) Run. We will start and finish at the Starbucks on Queens Blvd and 46th Street.


Details: 
8:00am, Starbucks in Sunnyside; 10:00–11:00 minute pace.

Watch the comments section for details about this week's MPLSD, including route, total distance and any other specifics that you'll need to know. Please make sure you are able to run the posted distance. This is for your safety and to help keep the group moving at a consistent pace. It's a good idea to bring your Metrocard and some cash in case you need to cut the run short. If you're a faster runner, please study the route in case you wish to run ahead.  

Be sure to bring along any fluids and/or nutrition you may need to successfully complete this distance. This is for your health, safety, and comfort.

results.description:
THE GAME

Informal Meet Up. 8 vs 8. 2 subs per team. No Permit. Be warned - there may or may not be a permitted event at the location which could cancel our game.

Bring a white and black t-shirt, and good attitude.

This game is ideally for intermediate to advanced players, not for beginners.

RSVP GUIDELINES. IMPORTANT:

- If you RSVP and don't show, you'll be benched from this group for the next two weeks. - If you can't make it, Un RSVP, to give others a chance to play.

- If you didn't RSVP or are on the Waitlist, you're at the bottom of the line.

PLAY GUIDELINES

- No slide tackles.

- Respect your teammates and opponents.

- If you fight, you will be banned from the group, permanently.

- If you dribble more than you pass - you annoy everybody and will be banned from the group.

POSITIONS:

Being a pick up game, there are no permanent positions. If you've been playing forward for half the game and someone who's been playing the back line wants to play up front, give up your position and play some defense. When your team lose the ball, don't just stand and watch. Please support your teammates by get back on your side and play some defense.

Thanks.

**INJURIES & DISCLAIMER**:

Group Organizer(s) and Group Organization Assumes NO Risk Or individual Liability For Personal Injuries Incurred By Members/Players On The Field Or During Any Of Our Activities: Pick Up Games, Or Other Events. results.description:
Yes the meetup time is 8:00AM!!

A couple of things. Saturday night/Sunday morning is roll back your clock by an hour day. Even though we're making it 8AM, it will really feel like 9AM. So you're actually arriving half an hour later than usual.

Secondly, Sunday is NYC marathon day. 4th Ave in Brooklyn is closed as well as parts of Verrazano bridge. Plan accordingly.

Last week we got lucky with the artificial field. I don't expect that this week so back to the sloping softball field as noted in this picture. It should be dry and crisp this Sunday. Come join us.

Again, please show up if you RSVP'ed and be on time!

Questions or problems then give me a call at[masked] but I usually won't be answering as I'll be setting up the field or playing...

***************

 
Attendance will be strictly enforced. No-shows will be marked and posted on the subsequent meetup. First time offenders will be given the benefit of doubt, second time offenders will be warned (consider your name in this email and the number of times you no-showed as warning) and those who miss a third time will be banned, permanently! Those that show up without RSVP to circumvent this will be warned as well. We need to know how many people will show up in order to decide if we have enough people for a game that week.

All new members are allowed to play for free the first three games. If you decide to continue with us then please remit the membership fee. Our season starts on 9/1 and the $10 is good for all games for the year

RSVP required


What equipment is required?

A mask, snorkel, fins and a weight belt suitable for SCUBA* and dive boots. A wetsuit is optional and recommended. We have special pricing for our students. Let us know when you would like to come in to be fitted for your student equipment package. Most important is that you will get the "Right Gear, the Right Fit at the Right Price" *Note: Snorkeling equipment is not always suitable for SCUBA activities.

Please arrive on time, late arrivals are subject to rescheduling and fees.

If you have any questions please email or call the shop

New Students, If this is your first pool session, you must:
1. Complete the required academics before the pool session;

Online Students must complete Chapters 1 -6CD Rom students must complete Sections 1-5

2. Bring a bathing suit and a towel. There are lockers in the changing room so bring a lock if you like.

3. Drink plenty of water before class

4. Don't forget to print out and bring your skills checklist.

5. Print out a copy of the Hand Signals to review and bring with you.

6. If you have not yet completed a "Student Folder" at the store.

Why it's a good idea for Divers to own their own SCUBA gear?

RSVP Now

results.description:
Join us for a Halloween time tradition with Metrotrails! Wear a costume (optional of course) and we'll do a hike, this time for fifteen or so miles looping around Sleepy Hollow NY!


https://scontent-iad3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xfp1/v/t1.0-9/406801_10151914698531777_502766194_n.jpg?oh=5981e12c87f4e02b95b6b124a622c43b&oe=56A6CEBF

We will start this hike at the Philipse Manor Train Station along the Hudson River, where we've started some of these hikes before. From there, we'll following along the Hudson to the south to start off with. From this vantage point, we will be able to see some of the new work being done on the replacement Tappan Zee Bridge.


Next, we'll follow a bit of the Old Croton Aqueduct, the first fresh water supply piped to NY City in the 1840s. The route is now a state historical trail. We won't be on it or long before cutting up hill a bit toward Tarrytown Reservoir.


https://scontent-iad3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xpf1/v/t1.0-9/400223_10151914697491777_1154570776_n.jpg?oh=e13cdbd751d953002930e439fffd3ee9&oe=56AB977C

Once at the Tarrytown Reservoir, we'll follow along the south shore on a paved trail there. This trail follows the original right of way of the Old Putnam Railroad line, prior to it being moved from the Rockefeller estate to a location further to the east. We'll touch this right of way a couple of times during the hike.


https://scontent-iad3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xap1/v/t1.0-9/1480663_10153188653801777_6540257466338729005_n.jpg?oh=96323cc5aa29ddd096d24f0d10719a79&oe=56740A25

The trail is pleasant as it leads along the shore, picks up the right of way, and then continues to a connection with the later route of the Old Put, now North County Trailway, but we will not be using this route for this hike.
Then, we may have a brief off trail section from the edge of the reservoir's east end we will briefly bushwhack up  hill to reach Rockefeller State Park Preserve trails.


https://scontent-iad3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xfa1/v/t1.0-9/10153839_10153188653426777_5635623432486964545_n.jpg?oh=ff607f8c457fb59e86ab4b5ff683ef61&oe=56ABA9C0

Some of the trails we will follow will include Perry Road Trail, Goat Trail, Raven Rock Trail, Laurence's Ridge Trail, Lucy's Loop Trail, Equestrian Trail, and many more. The exact route will depend on how much time we have left as we basically follow around the perimeter of Rockafeller State Park Preserve.


There should be some interesting stuff back there like the Raven's Rock and possible other overlooks. With many of the leaves down from the trees, we should have some more views this time of year.


The trails in the preserve range from rugged foot path to very easy paved or crushed stone surface so it should be interesting, and I won't know what each one of them are until we actually arrive and hike them.


https://scontent-iad3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xaf1/v/t1.0-9/182497_10151914697371777_1795870995_n.jpg?oh=dea1a380a2734b6ff721e37185feee3d&oe=566DD396

As we near the end, we will plan on entering the Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. This is the famous REAL Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, and on the way there we will literally hike Sleepy Hollow, which is the glen of the Pocantico River, quite a lovely place.


https://scontent-iad3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xpf1/v/t1.0-9/403470_10151914699181777_2101887371_n.jpg?oh=7f4a9b8687567db1c98b65bf32aeae96&oe=56AAAD21

If we have the time, we will visit the grave of Washington Irving himself, writer of the Sleepy Hollow stories including the Headless Horseman and Rip Van Winkle.
In addition to Irving, Andrew Carnegie is also buried in the cemetery, and we can visit his grave as well.


https://scontent-iad3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xfa1/v/t1.0-9/320310_10151914697851777_1504891425_n.jpg?oh=68a207a4c85992ebf42795e14e3d9caf&oe=5665493A

We will exit the cemetery at the Old Dutch Church. This amazing old church was constructed in 1697 and is still standing strong today. The church is located directly adjacent to the Headless Horseman Bridge. The original bridge of course is long gone, but the abutments to it remain, and the crossing is still known as the Headless Horseman Bridge.


https://scontent-iad3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-ash2/v/t1.0-9/487303_10151914700816777_686540647_n.jpg?oh=2694aae1001f8cd58ab21b3ef6eda115&oe=56A5CBC3

This is sure to be another great time romping around the east Hudson Valley.
Contact me if you have any further questions at my cell:[masked] ....
AND don't forget to CHANGE YOUR CLOCKS the night before, because it's daylight savings. Turn your clocks back! No excuses for lateness because you gain an hour of sleep!

Trail Work Crew
Sunday, August 2, 9:00 a.m.-noon.
Locust Grove Picnic Area. Ages 15+.

Help build new, or reroute or repair existing, hiking trails throughout the South Mountain Reservation following sustainable trail guidelines. Trail building is very satisfying, but can be hard work. We use hand tools such as picks and adzes to create and shape the trail tread. Wear shoes with solid soles and long pants…and for early spring, dress in layers. You provide the strong back; we provide gloves, a snack, water, and instruction.

In November, we are continuing our improvements to address water erosion issues a ten-to-fifteen-minute hike from Locust Grove. There will be some digging!

Leaders: If there are questions, call John Verzani [masked]), or Dennis Percher [masked]). Meet at: The Locust Grove Picnic Area, off Glen Ave., Millburn (opposite the intersection with Lackawana Place). (To see a map of the location, go to http://www.somocon.org/about-the-reservation/maps-of-locations/). This parking lot can be full on weekends. The nearby Millburn Library parking lot is an alternative.

Be advised that Brookside drive is closed on Sundays. This may cause an issue if using Google Maps, or some such, to navigate.

results.description:
Flag Football Game at Cunningham Park (196th St and Union Turnpike) in Queens. Come out and join us!

We have cones and flags so all you need is cleats if that is what you prefer. GAMES WILL ALWAYS BE PLAYED REGARDLESS OF THE WEATHER CONDITIONS i.e. rain, snow, cold, mud, ice, storm, hurricane, etc...we never cancel games due to weather...games are fun and competitive, all skill levels are welcome, please contact me if you have any questions.

NOTE: PLEASE RSVP "YES" ONLY IF YOU ARE GOING TO SHOW UP TO THE GAME.  YOU CAN CHANGE YOUR RSVP IF SOMETHING COMES UP (OR IF YOU DON'T WANT TO PLAY IF IT'S TOO COLD/IT'S RAINING/IT'S SNOWING) AND YOU CAN'T MAKE IT.  NO-SHOWS WILL BE REMOVE FROM THE GROUP.  IT IS IMPORTANT TO HAVE AN ACCURATE HEAD COUNT SO WE KNOW HOW MANY PEOPLE ARE REALLY COMING.

ere are some of the new changes we have made and a reminder of some of the guidelines we already have:

1) You can not add  guests to your RSVP.  Anyone is free to come and play IF AND ONLY IF you have a profile in meetup and have joined our group.  It's 100% FREE to join and it only takes about 2 minutes to sign up and RSVP.  There are also FREE mobile apps for iPhones and Android phones so you can RSVP easily on the go.  If any of your friends has been playing and wants to continue to play, ask them to go to http://www.meetup.com/Cunningham-Park-Football/ and sign up and RSVP individually.  YOU CAN NOT PLAY if you're not signed up and RSVPd.

2) The first 20 people that RSVP for the game, will play a 9-on-9 game with 1 sub.  Everyone on the waiting list will pick players and play against the winner of the game.  Games will be to 2 scores.  If a team gets 2 scores, with the score 2-1, the other team gets one (1) more possession to try to score and tie the game.  If the game is tied again, the game is now to 3 points and the same rule applies, once one of the teams gets score #3, the other team gets just one (1) more possession to try to tie the game.  If 20 or less players show up to the game, game can be played to whatever score everyone agrees to.

3) If you're one of the first 20 to RSVP, but you're late, the next person on the waiting list that's present on the field will take your place and play in the first game.

4) On a safety, ball stays at the goal line and the next down will be played.  For example: If a 2nd down play is ran and a safety occurs, the ball stays at the goal line and the 3rd down will be played.

5) On an OBVIOUS "Defensive Pass interference", the ball will stay at the line of scrimmage but you reset your plays and start at 1st down again.  For example: If a 3rd down play is ran and a DPI occurs, the ball stays at the line of scrimmage and a 1st down will be played, then 2nd, then 3rd...etc.

6) On an OBVIOUS "Offensive Pass interference", the ball stays at the line of scrimmage and the offensive time will lose a down.  For example: If a 2nd down play is ran and an OPI occurs, the offensive team will now be on a 4th down situation from the line of scrimmage.

7) As you might have noticed we have had very few injuries (knock on wood) throughout the years.  This is why we wanted to remind you of the following:

-Stiff arming, flag guarding and hand slapping are NOT ALLOWED.

-Blocks from the back are NOT allowed ad they're obviously dangerous and can cause injuries.

-VERY IMPORTANT: If you are the offensive player and have the ball in your hands, you MUST avoid contact and CAN NOT under any circumstances lower your shoulders and try to initiate contact with an defensive player.  This is flag football, if you're looking for a different type of game there are plenty of other places and leagues to play flag or full-contact football.

8) Donations:  I pay the monthly fee for hosting these meetups and never charge anyone.  All we asked for you is to drop at least $1 in the container we have set up for this, all the money is used for equipment, flags, cones, etc.  You can click on "Group Tools > Money" and see where all the money is going.  If we buy anything with that money we record the transaction and upload a picture of the receipt of whatever equipment we bought.  Next thing we want to get are end zone weighted pylons and we want to buy orange rope so we can mark the field faster and more accurately to avoid any arguments about where the first down is or what not.

IMPORTANT: WE ARE ALL ADULTS AND OBVIOUSLY CAN'T FORCE ANYONE TO DO ANYTHING.  WE NEED EVERYONE'S COOPERATION TO FOLLOW THESE SIMPLE GUIDELINES TO KEEP THE GAME FUN AND COMPETITIVE.  IF FOR ANY REASON YOU DISAGREE OR BELIEVE THAT THESE GUIDELINES DO NOT FIT YOUR STYLE OF PLAY OR WHAT YOU'RE LOOKING FOR ON A PICK-UP GAME, YOU'RE WELCOME TO PLAY WITH A DIFFERENT MEETUP GROUP OR IN ANY OTHER PICK-UP GAME...NO HARD FEELINGS.

If you have any suggestions, questions or concerns, please feel free to reach me at[masked] or [masked]

Regards,

Carlos

results.description:
This event is proudly brought to you by Soccer Beyond!

Learn more on SoccerBeyond.com or Facebook.com/SoccerBeyond.

Details - Fun, interactive, effective.

90min. This is a Coed Soccer Lesson. Please bring a ball if you have. Sneakers, running and turf shoes are fine. Bring some water or sports drink and maybe sun blocker. Please note our Waiver of Liability and 24hr Cancellation Policy below. More details follow.

Rain or Shine - If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Our sessions will be held as scheduled if weather allows. Thunder or snow and ice are among the reasons for sessions to be canceled/ moved. BUT: Don't make assumptions - you will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved. As the weather changes quickly in NYC, occasionally we may make the final decision about 90min prior to session start. If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Cancelled/ Moved Sessions - You will always get notified!

Every time we have to cancel a session, if possible, we move it to the same day and time of the following week. In this case, all players keep their spots. Please email us prior to the rescheduled event, if you can't make and wish a refund or credit. The 24 hours cancellation policy applies. You will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved.

Requesting a Refund

To request a refund 1) change your status to "not going" and 2) send us a note with the Paypal transaction number related to the payment for the respective session. Refunds are processed once a week - please be patient.


24 Hours Cancellation Policy

A full refund/ credit will be given if cancellation is received at least 24 hours prior to lesson start. Full payment is required thereafter. Our cancellation policy also applies to package holders.


Waiver of Liability and Hold Harmless Agreement

By RSVP'ing for this event you certify that you are physically fit such as you are able to participate in this program. You therewith voluntarily release CoachFrankNYC/ Soccer Beyond, LLC from any and all liability resulting from or arising out of your participation and/ or receipt of instruction. You read and agree to the WAIVER OF LIABILITY AND HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT to be found on SoccerBeyond.com/pages/waiver.

Please let us know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Coach Frank

All players must bring a white and a dark shirt (not grey). This is a friendly run. Anyone with the wrong attitude will not be allowed back. Age: 21+

The A/B & B/C breakdown is purely a self rating device to try and split things up in an enjoyable manner. Think of it as if you were going to the park to play. results.description:
Reiki I Training & Certification Class

https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/Zt264ADlbTCuBPzcTsf6MEufffU_jyiAEV7vXEyd2ZASnMxvB99zGWtdyiVEqxIaP4Y2WjSJOS3hX7dmPSc7Uyzc2GuOy9-iSJboYLMI61DoLAzgCtoEKcJqc2i0b4epQXdSaI95 Reiki is a Japanese technique for stress reduction and relaxation that also promotes healing. It is spiritually guided life-force energy that is transferred through the practitioner to the client via gentle laying of hands on or off the body. Reiki treats the whole person including body, emotions, mind and spirit creating many beneficial effects that include relaxation and feelings of peace, security and well-being. Reiki is a simple, natural and safe method of spiritual healing and self-improvement that everyone can use and enhances the body's natural ability to heal itself. It has been effective in helping virtually every known illness and always creates a beneficial effect. It also works in conjunction with all other medical or therapeutic techniques to relieve side effects and promote recovery.


Reiki I training will cover:
- What is Reiki
- How does it work
- What can it heal
- History of Reiki (both Japanese and Western history)
- Ethics in Reiki
- Reiki I attunement and meditation
- Learning hand positions
- Plenty of time to practice with each other 

* We will have a 1 hour lunch break. Please feel free to pack one and bring with you.
* You will receive a certificate as a Reiki I Practitioner upon successful completion of the class. 

Cost is $150 including manual and certificate. 

Please email Sarah to register and reserve your space.
[masked] 

Sarah Milligan
Reiki Master-Teacher, Medium, Health & Fitness Coach

results.description:
If you haven't been out in a while now is the time to come out and join us for another fun filled day in the saddle.  So pull the cover off your sport bike, cruiser, or touring bike, and grab your winter gear because we are on a mission to explore new and exciting roads.  The route is still being planned but who cares as long as we get another ride in.  Weather looks promising but please dress warm.  Remember, back roads are usually a bit colder.  and yes, I will be bringing out my cruiser.  Should be fun!

Meet at the usual spot.  KSU@ 10:30am

See you then..

DRod

Route update:

We will take back roads to Bear Mtn, cross Hudson, take some old and new twisties in Harriman SP, go around Greenwood lake to visit Buttermilk Falls, take back roads north to Newburgh, cross Hudson again, take route 9D south and stop by two more waterfalls (missed last time), finally follow route 9 back home.

The ride should be fun, beautiful and interesting.

Lunch location TBD. Please bring light snack and warm clothes. We will make frequent stops to take pics and relax.

Total trip length about 170 miles.
results.name: More waterfalls, foliage and twisties

results.description:
Meeting Details sent out Friday at 6:40 P.M. If you do not receive, check spam first, contact me ASAP, don't post a comment, and provide your e-mail address and I will resend.


RSVP'S CLOSED

PLEASE READ THIS CAREFULLY BEFORE YOU RSVP. I TAKE THE RSVP PROCESS VERY SERIOUSLY AND EXPECT THAT YOU SHOULD TOO.

Join me and AMC Club members who do not have to RSVP-unless they do not get last minute e-mails from the Club through Yahoo- on a fast paced, fun 5 mile hiking tour around and through Prospect Park. This will be the third time I am leading this for the Club and this time will be even better than the last two. We will stop a number of times to very briefly talk about what we see. Vaux and Olmstead, the designers of both Central Park and Prospect Park, considered Prospect Park their masterpiece. Hopefully, we will see why. In many ways-size, shape, number of structures etc, etc-Prospect Park is different than Central Park. WE WILL FINISH AROUND 1:30 OR SO. NO LUNCH STOP.

We leave ON TIME. BE READY TO GO. I WILL SEND AN E-MAIL WITH MEETING DETAILS A DAY BEFORE THE EVENT.

Please consider joining the Appalachian Mountain Club (AMC) ) http://www.amc-ny.org/ The Club offers many hikes, walks and events and is also active in conservation efforts and trail maintenance. Only a few of the many hikes and walks that are offered by AMC leaders are posted on Meetup. 

Since this event will be posted as a last minute hike to AMC Club members, there is NO need for AMC Club members to RSVP for this-unless you don’t get last minute e-mails from Yahoo. (Contact me a day or so before the hike if you are a dues paying AMC Club member and don’t get these e-mails and I’ll tell you how).  Let’s leave 10 spaces for AMC Meetup members. Priority will be given to those who have previously attended other AMC Meetup events-it does not have to be mine-and have some attachment to the Club.

Needless to say, please take the RSVP process seriously and be considerate. If you have been a NO SHOW on any AMC Meetup event that I have led –see your attendance history-or you are a chronic abuser of the RSVP process, please do not RSVP because I am just going to delete it. I am going to ask that people not post any comments or questions prior to the event. You will have all the information you need to do this once you get the meeting place details. No offense, but I don’t need to know what you are doing that day (and probably neither does anyone else) if you can’t make it or what you think the weather will be. AFTER the event, post as many comments and photos as you like.

If the weather is really bad or there is a really bad forecast, Check Accuweather like I do, I will post a notice by very early on the day of the event cancelling. If there is no notice, we go.

Platform presentation by Margaret Von der Meden.

Margaret will look at the role of the honeybee in ancient times, how they arrived in North America and what events caused the decline of the honeybee.  We will explore ways to become stewards of the honeybee in our own backyards.

Margaret has been a beekeeper in the Hudson Valley for over 20 years. She also teaches  hands-on Curriculum Enhancement workshops in Westchester and Connecticut in various  subjects and enjoys bringing her observation Hive into the classroom.

Light refreshments after the program.

Regular Ethics for Children classes today.

Please join us for today's service led by Rev. Paul Dodenhoff. Samhain (pronounced /ˈsɑːwɪn/ SAH-win or /ˈsaʊ.ɪn/ SOW-in) is an ancient Celtic and pagan festival marking the end of the harvest season and the beginning the "darker half" of the year. It's a time when the ancestors are honored, divinations for the New Year are performed, and festivals are held in honor of the gods. Join us as we celebrate this ancient, meaningful holiday. Bright clothing recommended! Costumes welcome, too!!

Bring a friend and stay for coffee and great conversation. We look forward to seeing you!

results.description:
It's time to get kicking. Kick your neighbor. Kick your brother. Kick the big red ball. Just don't kick your dog. Game. On.

If you don't know, now you know ...

If you've never played the game of kickball as a kid you must have grown up on Mars. But as a quick primer, it's a game with rules similar to baseball -- except instead of using a bat to hit a little ball, you use your feet to kick a ball about 10x the size of a baseball. Kick the ball, run to the base, avoid getting your ball caught mid-air or yourself tagged out. Easy. And no athletic skill is necessary, just the ability to kick! Go out and practice now to get ready. Kick the postman when he delivers your bills. Kick that neighbor who won't turn down his stereo. Just get kicking!

If you haven't played the game in 20 years, here are the general rules we will be using https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/64476072/Kickball%20Rules.pdf.</a>

A $3.00 organization fee will be collected at this event, your host is in the running for hardest working person on meetup.

The important stuff ...

• This is a co-ed game so ladies don't be shy to sign up. And it doesn't matter if you have no athletic ability, you just have to be willing to have a little fun.

• Dress for physical activity! You'll be kicking and running so wear your sneaks, shorts and a t-shirt.

• Rain or similar un-favorable weather cancels the meetup. Not!

• Check the meetup site before leaving for last minute updates as well as my mobile phone number.

• Please DO NOT RSVP if you do not seriously plan to attend as space is limited. No flakes allowed! If you RSVP and I notice that you have a number of no shows or have a history of last minute cancellations, you will be removed.

• Sorry, no guests allowed for this one.

Launched in 1996, Idealist has become one of the most popular nonprofit resources on the web, with information provided by 100,000 organizations around the world and two million visitors every month. Ami was born in Jerusalem, grew up in Peru and in Mexico, and lives in New York.

We're excited to announce that the Brooklyn Ark will start a morning service Sunday, November 1st at 11am. Many people have been waiting for this day, and are so excited it has come! The 6:30pm service will continue as usual. Let us know which service works the best for you.

ABOUT US 

Welcome! Brooklyn Ark (Manhattan Campus) is an exciting faith and networking community that meets on Wall Street in Manhattan. If you are looking for a church, synagogue, or just somewhere to meet friends and wrestle with the deep questions of life, this is a perfect place for you. 


WHEN WE MEET 

Sunday Morning Service at 11:00am starting Sunday, November 1st with after-party networking *Sunday Evening Service at 6:30pm with after-party networking Get connected at the many mid-week Bible studies and community events throughout the week.

WHERE WE MEET 

*48 Wall Street, Manhattan, NY (Financial District)
*Take any of these convenient lines: 2/3, J/Z, and 4/5. A few blocks further you'll find the 1, R, A/C, and PATH at World Trade Center. You'll also find the Staten Island Ferry Whitehall Terminal to be a 10-minute walk away. 

Visit out website for more information: http://www.brooklynark.com/

Speaker: Jone Johnson Lewis, Leader

Details: Sounds a bit like a paradox: freethinkers in community.  Yet freedom and social connection are both crucial for human flourishing. Leader Jone Johnson Lewis will reflect on what kind ofcommunity fits the needs of freethinkers, what freethinkers bring to community that’s special.  Beyond that, what also inspires us to move beyond our own narrow needs to address the needs of other individuals, locally and globally, and the human community as a whole?</a>

About the Speaker: Jone Johnson Lewis is the clergy Leader of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. Jone has been an Ethical Culture Leader since 1991, serving Ethical Societies in Chicago, Northern Virginia and Brooklyn. She's currently the President of the National Council of Leaders and a member of the American Ethical Union's Membership Committee. 

For more information: http://www.rysec.org/event/community-for-freethinkers


Sunday programs are held at 11:00 AM at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. For more information, please visit our website: <a>http://www.rysec.org

results.description:
Games have been around for thousands of years, and yet it's not until recently that much thought has been given to the way in which games educate. Modern games can place players into moral dilemmas that will test their ethical boundaries or enable them to step into the shoes with whom they would normally not be able to empathize. Perhaps more important than direct ethical content, some games force players to work together in teams to accomplish a common goal, which research shows may be the most important ethical exercise of all. Paulo Ribeiro will explore the field of tabletop, digital, and live action games on the market today that push the bounds of creativity and nurture crucial values and social skills.

Paulo Ribeiro is a Leader-in-Training with the American Ethical Union. He holds a BA from Montclair State University in Sociology and is a recent graduate of the Humanist Institute. He is a three-time recipient of the US President's Volunteer Service Award for his work with children's education and recreation programs.
results.name: Paulo Ribeiro: Learning Ethics through Games

results.description:
Are you looking to BALANCE your training & stretching?

Are you looking for RELIEF from joint wear, tightness, pain, and/or discomfort?

Looking for a complementary training to ENHANCE your overall well being on and off the track?

Would you like to RELEASE physical, mental and emotional tensions?

About Yin Yang Yoga...A typical Yoga class is ‘Yang’ in style and focuses on active heating and muscular contraction - by combining it with ‘Yin’, a more passive, nourishing, and cooling practice, this uniquely designed class WILL balance your whole being in training!

Why For Runners/Athletes? - Lengthening and releasing effect from repetitive movements (overuse) on sheets of connective tissue can overtime shorten and tighten in ingrained patterns around muscles. This fascia restriction can make one more prone to having injuries, abnormal posture, and inefficiency, as well as asymmetrical weakening. By targeting rotated key areas in weekly Yin Yang Yoga class, one can better release tension, move with ease, and benefit from improved posture and injury prevention.  In addition, increased respiratory control and focus have been reported by students.

The Yin Yang Yoga for Runners class begins with series of held Yin floor postures to open the meridian/chakras pathways of the body. While surrendering into the edge of each pose for 2-5 minutes, students are guided in the cultivation of observance and breath, as they experience release of connective tissues and the stagnant energy around the hips, thighs, and lower back. Awareness is emphasized to sensations in the body that are grounding and powerful experience of the NOW. The Yang or moving practice allows students to integrate the newly released energy, joint spaces for circulation, and flexibility, into vigorous strengthening postures and movement sequences. Freedom of breath, alignment, and mental clarity will be elicited deeply during, after the class, and into one's training.

After our INTRO CLASS ON 9/10: "Jennifer is an awesome instructor. Her sessions are informative and her teaching style is patient, clear and inspires me to attain increased fitness. I look forward to attending her class. The very next day I was able to push through my usual 3-4 miles to complete a 6 mile run." Sandra

AND another student reported achieving best time running a 18 mile course...


**10 Classes Only - Join weekly for maximum benefits and donate suggested $15 per class for this this performance enhancing class not offered anywhere else in NYC!


Please message me other days/times for Spring Program Offering considerations.  Thank you!


Namaste, Jennifer, RYT-500hr

results.description:
Prospect Park is a great place for foragers to explore at the end of the winter. Like Central Park, this Olmstead-designed landscape features a variety of habitats filled with delicious native and exotic plants.

Wild coffee grows within a few minutes walk of the Grand Army Plaza entrance. Unrelated to commercial coffee, we'll collect the seeds of the little-known Kentucky coffee-tree, the world's best caffeine-free coffee substitute. You can use them to make a coffee-like beverage, or as a seasoning that's terrific in chocolate recipes.

Learn more details about this event: https://goo.gl/3Ldawy 
Book Your spot: https://goo.gl/3Ldawy
results.name: Learn How to Forage in the Heart of the Urban Jungle - Prospect Park Edition!

results.description:
Prospect Park is a great place for foragers to explore at the end of the winter. Like Central Park, this Olmstead-designed landscape features a variety of habitats filled with delicious native and exotic plants.

Wild coffee grows within a few minutes walk of the Grand Army Plaza entrance. Unrelated to commercial coffee, we'll collect the seeds of the little-known Kentucky coffee-tree, the world's best caffeine-free coffee substitute. You can use them to make a coffee-like beverage, or as a seasoning that's terrific in chocolate recipes.

Cold weather greens abound throughout the park. We'll find garlic-flavored garlic mustard greens and sprouts, which taste like garlic, and their roots, which taste like horseradish. We'll look for chickweed, which tastes like corn, bitter dock, as delicious cooked as it's awful raw, and ground ivy, a mint-flavored herb tea.

Location: It's in Brooklyn, the exact address is on Tickets

Tickets are sold here: https://goo.gl/v0mqge

Both sweet-sharp daylily shoots, and chive-like field garlic will already be producing bumper crops in the cold weather.

East of the boathouse, we'll examine a dense stand of chicory, growing along with the ubiquitous dandelions. Both greens have a savory-bitter flavor, and they're at their best right now, before they flower.

Throughout the park, we'll look for stands goutweed, an herb that tastes like parsley and celery. It does great in the cold weather.

The first tiny leaves of wild parsnips, growing just west of the skating rink, will clue us in to the location of the large, sweet roots. And the abundant, green, fragrant twigs of sassafras saplings, which grow in woods throughout, will let us find roots for making wild root beer.

And we'll be able to observe the first wildflowers of the season on witch hazel, hazelnut, common spicebush, and cornelian cherry bushes. These blossoms are tiny, since there are few insects to attract, but "Wildman’s" jeweler's loupes will make all the details clearly visible.
results.name: Learn How to Forage in the Heart of the Urban Jungle

results.description:
This is a co-ed adult pick-up game 6v6 or 7 v7 depending on attendance. 90 minutes with two 45 minute halves. No slide tackling or rough play. We play with Pugg goals. Pinnies provided.  Shin guards are recommended.


This pick up game is hosted by Coach Moe, Please bring  $4 in cash.


PLEASE UPDATE YOUR RSVP BY MIDNIGHT BEFORE THE GAME!

• RSVPs close by 9:45AM (2 hours before the start time)


• No shows and those who didn't update their RSVP at least 2 hours before the game will be red carded after the second offense, which means that we have the right to edit your RSVP.


Directions by subway or bus:

2 and 3 trains to Clark St.

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.


Weather policy:

In case of inclement weather we will send out an email to notify you at least two hours before meeting time.

What to bring:

Please note that Cadman Plaza park is a turf field. Turf shoes are preferred. Please bring water or sports drink. Please bring a ball if you have one.


By RSVP-ing YES you agree to the following:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Brooklyn Soccer Club activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Brooklyn Soccer Club Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Brooklyn Soccer Club or activities.
results.how_to_find_us: Coach Moe will be wearing a neon yellow pinnie.

We are excited to be joining other local groups in NYC and NYC metro in Berning the NYC Marathon—a great chance to reach a massive crowd with the Marathon and show the city how strong New York’s local grassroots support for Bernie is. It should be a great vibe and great fun!

There are 26 designated stations - we will be representing our group at this stop at Duke Ellignton Circle.

On the day of, please show up in your finest Bernie swag with flyers or banners in hand. Think about signs of encouragement for the runners—“You are amazing, runners! Love, Bernie Supporter” (or Love, Chelsea for Bernie, etc.) Or simply “Go runners for Bernie!”.

Join us, and help spread the word!

P.s.: Runners: do we have anyone running the marathon in our group? If so, sign up on the same two links above then show up and show your support by running in your Bernie gear. We’‘ll be cheering for you in our station!

results.description:
In this workshop students will make their own natural indigo dye bath, and learn about the basics of Shibori and dye patterning techniques.

We will go over: 
prepping the dye bath 
prepping the fabrics and fibers 
bundling, binding and folding fabrics for shibori 
dying and experimenting with depths of color 
washing and caring for your indigo dyed products 
Fabric will be provided for experimenting, while students are also encouraged to bring an item to dye that is of a light color and natural fibers (silk, linen, cotton only). We will also provide some fabric items for the students to be able to take away with them at the end of the workshop. 
Indigo dyes quickly and easily, and we will provide plastic aprons, but please don't wear your favorite clothes to this workshop with risk of getting dye on them!

Location: On Tickets

The tickets are sold here: https://goo.gl/1GyxCB

About Designer:

Apprvl came about in the summer of 2014 by Megan Mussari, as product of curiosity in natural dyes and a desire to make quality products by hand. After working in the fashion and textiles industry, seeing and feeling first hand the effects of synthetic dyes in mass production, the studies and experimentations began. Apprvl's collection of unique goods are handmade & hand dyed in NYC from natural dyes and fibers. By embracing the beauty of human error, each design is truly one of a kind.
results.name: The Essential of Shibori Indigo Dyeing

results.description:
A small, supportive group for artists of all types to come together and talk about and share their creative projects in a fun, non-judgmental environment. New members welcome. (Each person pays $1 cash at the meetings, just to help offset the costs of having the group hosted here on MeetUp.com.)

Every week, we meet from 12:00 pm to 2:00 pm. Usually, we work through Julia Cameron's creativity building techniques (for example those in The Artist's Way and The Prosperous Heart). We start each session discussing the current week's activity (morning pages, artist's dates, synchronicities, creative endeavors, etc) and then participate in an agreed upon exercise/task (bring paper and pen please).


Normally, on the third Sunday of the month, we share our artistic projects in a kind of "Show & Tell" so that we can get to know each other's work and support it. Not mandatory - only for those who wish to share or present their work.


This is a very creative and supportive small group. Please join us.
results.name: The Artist's Way

results.description:
Experience the beauty of the night sky with Stan Honda. A photojournalist with 34 years of experience, Stan will show us the beauty of the sky and why we need to preserve this diminishing resource. Stan will walk you through various techniques and camera settings necessary to get amazing DSLR photographs of the Milky Way, the moon, the stars, and other objects that populate the night sky. Stan will show the beauty of the sky and why we need to preserve this diminishing resource. After walking you through how to capture these images, Stan will provide a brief tutorial on how best to process these images on a computer so that your images will fill yoru viewers with the same sense of wonder that the starry sky does.

ABOUT STAN:
Stan Honda is a photojournalist with 34 years of experience in New York City and southern California. Over the past few years he has also been working on wide-angle night sky landscapes and other astronomical images taken in locations around the world and even in New York. He has been a National Park Service artist-in-residence in four national parks. Stan’s recent photos have appeared in NASA’s Astronomy Picture of the Day website, Sky and Telescope magazine and a Yahoo News slideshow on his night sky photos. He recently had a solo exhibit of the photographs in a Flagstaff, AZ arts center.

Learn more about Stan at www.stanhonda.com
results.name: Shooting Stars with Stan Honda

results.description:
Updated October 8th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

FALL (Sep - Nov)

As the city cools down we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park on weekdays and Morningside Park for weekends.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th & Manhattan Ave) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Morningside Park (110th & Manhattan Ave) 
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End) 
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)

Damien 
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

results.description:
Announcement: As of today, I have and am still getting a lot of comments/complaints regarding the details of this meet up. Some people appear to not read all the updates.

As the organizer, I choose where we eat and usually, we see one movie I pick, then we eat to discuss the film and life. This time I offered choices, which I will not do again, since it seemed to create too many issues.

We usually go to Edgewater Multiplex because it's never a problem to park or get in, they have big screens, 3D, recliners in some theaters, and as Starpass Rewards members, we get fee movies all the time.

The movies are not announced till Wednesday, except for Starplex which was announced today.

As I posted below, SUFFRAGETTE IS NOT OPENING ANYWHERE. 

The same films with the exception of TRUTH are at Starplex. However, I am not a fan of Starplex because as I said, you need to buy a ticket online and need to be there at least 45 minutes before to sit together.

I will be seeing either Steve Jobs or Truth, as are at least two other members that I know of. Since we are eating before the movie this time, it's not imperative to see the same films. If people want, after the movie, we can go for coffee as we've done before.

Therefore, anyone can go to wherever they want after brunch to see what they like.

My sole purpose in creating this meetup was to find other true cinephiles, discuss movies and make new friends. Anyone can go alone to a movie, but why should you?

We have had 10 meetup's thus far and all have been great. I work hard to ensure that everyone meets and gets introduced and feels comfortable. 

If you RSVPd for Sunday, I look forward to seeing you at 12pm.

The movies at Edgewater that I would see are:

Bridge of Spies 3:00 

Steve Jobs 4:15

Burnt 2:10 4:35

Our Brand is Crisis 2:25 4:55

Truth 3:10

The Intern 3:05

Sicario 4:30

The other films are The Martian,  Paranormal Activity, Goosebumps, Last Witch Hunter,Scouts Guide to the Apocalypse.

Menu for MK Valencia brunch

results.description:
Please join LI-DOG for a Pack Walk--a group on-leash dog walk--on the beautiful grounds of Old Westbury Gardens during the OWG Fall Dog Festival on Sun., Nov. 1st!

Our Pack Walk will start Sunday morning at Noon and take 45-60 minutes as we stroll the beautiful grounds of this historic estate. The walk is almost all on flat ground and there are plenty of opportunities to shorten the walk for those who wish to do so. This is a great opportunity to enjoy this special place with your dog as the grounds are open to dog owners and their dogs only twice a year. This is also a great way to meet and socialize with other dog owners, get some exercise and have fun! Make sure to bring poop bags--as clean up is a must--and bring your camera as there are many beautiful photo opportunities. Please be by our table or by the LI-DOG banner by 11:45 a.m. to sign in.

Our Pack Walk is being held in conjunction with the Old Westbury Gardens Fall Dog Festival. The Festival features exhibiters like LI-DOG and other animal advocacy and rescue organizations, vendors of doggy treats and gear, and other fun activities! Exhibiters will be on the grounds Sunday from 11 a.m. until 4 p.m. In addition, there will be a dog costume parade starting at 3 p.m., so don't forget to bring your pup dressed in their Halloween best. Make sure to sign in and get your number from the OWG staff.

LI-DOG Raffle. Don't forget to get tickets at the LI-DOG table for a chance to win a basket of toys and treats for your pup! Donate $5 to LI-DOG and receive 1 ticket. Donate $10 and get 4 chances to win!  We will draw the winner at the end of the Pack Walk and you must be present to win.

Admission: There is an admission fee for Old Westbury Gardens. Adults are $10; adults over age 62 are $8; children ages 7-17 are $5; and children under 7, dogs, and OWG members are FREE!

Old Westbury Gardens is hosting Dog Days on both Sat. and Sun., Oct. 31st and Nov. 1st. The grounds are open for your and your leashed dog's enjoyment from 10 a.m. until 5 p.m.

The Fall Dog Festival is scheduled for Sun., Nov. 1st only. The LI-DOG Pack Walk will also be held on Sun., Nov. 1st.

Please remember: Dogs must be on-leash at all times when visiting the Gardens and are not allowed in any buildings on the grounds.

This is one of our favorite events of the year, so we hope you can join us!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the LI-DOG Tent and Banner!

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE AND TRANSPORTATION SECTION.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you.

A Lyndhurst Estate spokesperson said that Fall foliage was "quite gorgeous" on 10/19/2015. So Fall foliage might still be in full bloom on 11/1/2015!

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John, the event host, who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photograph. Thank you again.

Description:  We will be walking from the Irvington Metro-North train station and then going past historically significant houses/mansions designed by famous architects. We will first walk past the beautiful and unusual Armour-Stiner House. We'll then view Villa Lewaro, a palatial white stucco red-tiled roof mansion with 34 rooms. Later on, we'll be going to the Lyndhurst Estate. Overlooking the Hudson River, the 67-acre Lyndhurst Estate (named after the Linden trees planted on the estate) has a Gilded Age, Gothic-style mansion, huge carriage house, two-lane bowling alley, rose garden, and greenhouse. The Lyndhurst Estate has more grassy lawn space than medium-sized parks in NYC (including Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn). 

Below is Lyndhurst's romantic rose garden where we will have lunch.

We'll be having lunch at about 1:50 PM at the rose garden of the picturesque Lyndhurst Estate. For lunchtime, bring a blanket or something to sit on the grass. There are not many benches or rocks to sit on around the estate. There also is no place to buy lunch at the Lyndhurst Estate. After we eat lunch, we'll explore the beautiful grounds of the Lyndhurst Estate.

We don't have to pay to enter the grounds of the Lyndhurst Estate because there is no admission fee for those who walk in. However, those who drive into the estate have to pay an admission fee of $5 per person in the vehicle, but this fee does not apply on a weekday or in the winter months.

Below is the Old Croton Aqueduct path with a ventilator. The Old Croton Aqueduct is an easy, leveled dirt path. We'll occasionally be walking on the Old Croton Aqueduct, which will connect us to historic mansions/houses. But we'll mostly be walking on paved trails or sidewalks. In 1992, the Old Croton Aqueduct was awarded National Historic Landmark status.

Bring lunch, sun protection, water, EXTRA LAYERS OF CLOTHING, and comfortable walking shoes.

This is a sociable walk along a very scenic route filled with interesting places. Although I will comment on some things (the architecture and social history of these houses/mansions) along the way, this is not one of my walking tours.

This walk is about 4 1/2 miles and moderate paced. If you think that you will be lagging behind with a moderate pace, then this type of walk is not good for you.

Below was an aerial view of the Armour-Stiner House in April, 1978. (Photo Historic American Building Survey)

Below was the veranda of the Armour-Stiner House in April, 1978. (Photo Historic American Building Survey)

Below was inside the dome of the Armour-Stiner House in April, 1978. Over the last twenty five years, the house, including the dome, has been beautifully restored. (Photo Historic American Building Survey)


Below is Villa Lewaro in Irvington, NY. The original owner was entrepreneur Madam C. J. Walker. This privately-owned mansion is adjacent to the Croton Aqeduct.

Below was one of Madam C.J. Walker's hair products.

Below was Madam C. J. Walker at the wheel of her Waverly electric car, circa 1913. She owned three automobiles.

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer's Meetup preparation costs and fees.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you very much. 

Meeting Time: The meeting time is (before lunch) at 12:15 PM. (Bring your lunch.)

Meeting Place: The meeting place is outside of the entrance to the Red Barn Bakery at 4 South Astor Street, Irvington, NY 10533. The Red Barn Bakery is on the southern end of the Irvington Metro-North train station. (IF THE TRAIN IS LATE, THE ORGANIZER WILL WAIT FOR THE LATE-ARRIVING TRAIN.)

Before the walk, restrooms are available in the Red Barn Bakery. Later on, restrooms will be available on the Lyndhurst Estate.

Below is outside of the entrance to the Red Barn Bakery in Irvington, NY.

Below are the transportation options.

Public Transportation by Metro-North (from the Marble Hill station):  Take the No. 1 subway train to Marble Hill/225th Street, which is one block from the Metro-North's Marble Hill station. Then take the 11:42 AM Metro-North train from Marble Hill to Irvington, arriving at 12:09 PM. Before boarding the train, buy a ticket at the station's vending machine. Get a ticket from Marble Hill to Irvington (Regular fare is $3.75 one way; senior fare [65 years and older] is $1.75 one way). You can buy two tickets (one from Marble Hill to Irvington and one from Irvington back to Marble Hill). Purchasing a regular fare ticket on board the train is considerably more expensive. However, seniors citizens who show the proper identification may purchase a ticket on board the train without paying the penalty of the higher on board prices. (This Metro-North Marble Hill station is a good option for those who live on the West Side of Manhattan, have easy access to the No. 1 subway train, or want to save some money.)

Public Transportation by Metro-North (from Grand Central Terminal): From Grand Central Terminal, take the 11:20 AM Croton Harmon train that stops in Irvington at 12:09 PM. Before boarding the train, buy a ticket at Grand Central Terminal's vending machine or ticket window. Get a ticket from Grand Central Terminal to Irvington (Regular fare is $8.75 one way; senior fare [65 years and older] is $5.75 one way). You can buy two tickets (one from Grand Central Terminal to Irvington and one from Irvington back to Grand Central Terminal). Purchasing a regular fare ticket on board the train is considerably more expensive. However, seniors citizens who show the proper identification may purchase a ticket on board the train without paying the penalty of the higher on board prices.

Below is a schedule of Metro-North's Hudson Line on the weekend.

http://web.mta.info/mnr/html/planning/schedules/pdf/HUD_SS_apr262015.pdf

Driving: You can leave your car for the entire walk in the Irvington Metro-North parking lot, which is free on weekends. However, read carefully all the parking signs. For example, if you have a large vehicle don't park in a parking spot reserved for a compact vehicle. Wait for the train people outside of the Red Barn Bakery, near southern end of the station.

Finishing Time/Place:  We will be finishing back at the Irvington Metro-North station at about 4:20 PM. The return train arrives at Irvington at 4:48 PM, stopping in Marble Hill at 5:15 PM and Grand Central Terminal at 5:42 PM. (We might even have time to catch the earlier train, which is the 4:17 PM.)

Rainy weather or extremely cold conditions cancels this walk. Therefore, if it is rainy weather or extremely cold conditions, or the forecast is for rainy weather or extremely cold conditions, I will post a cancellation notice Sunday morning. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place (Red Barn Bakery at Irvington, NY).

Below are photos of the Gilded Age Lyndhurst Mansion and Estate, the former country home of Jay Gould.

Below is a political cartoon about Jay Gould. (Source Puck Magazine, March 29, 1882)

results.description:
Note: Only RSVP if you are planning to show up.

First Timers, READ details before you RSVP. 

Where: The Cliffs at LIC, [masked]th Drive, Long Island City, NY

When: We usually climb between 1:00pm and 4:00 pm. There is no strict start time and the organizer(s) tries their best to be there around 1:00pm. We will pair off around 1.15ish and start climbing. 

Transportation: Subway: E, M trains to 23rd St-Ely Ave (1/2 block from gym) 7, G train to Court Square (2 blocks from gym)* N, Q train to Queens Borough Plaza (10min walk) *Walk to the E & M track for those bad weather days 

Metro North & LIRR: From Grand Central take 7 train 3 stops From Penn Station take Uptown E train to Court Square

Cost/Discount: Monthly membership of $105 (the $99 Initiation Fee is waived if you sign up during the meet up). Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount. Gear rental is free for first-timers ONLY  (first time visit to the facility). Regular gear  pricing info can be found here: http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/climbing/pricing/
For Beginners, Climbing 101 class is offered 50% Off if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them.</a>

How to meet us:  After you checked-in, to the right of the front desk there's a sitting area.If you see a group of people in there that's probably us come and say hi. If you are running late or can't find the group leave a message in the Comments section.  Food/drinks apres-climb at John Brown Smokehouse next door (or whichever resto the group decides). Even if you only want to have a beer with us, that is also acceptable :)

Notice to Beginners: If you have never climbed before, we encourage you to take the Climbing 101 class there before attending the meetup. We get a discounted price of $25 for the class (that's 50% Off original price if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them). This will also cover your day pass + gear for the day. Unfortunately we can't teach you how to belay or let you try to belay at the gym if you are not belay certified yet. We leave the teaching to the experts.  Check out Cliff's website for more details.  What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, please see feel free to see me. Here is the link to The Cliffs LIC <a href="http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/">http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.  Also if you find this group invaluable, please donate and pay your voluntary membership due ;) the Organizers will love you more ;)
results.name: Weekend Climbing at the Cliffs LIC

Hello deliberate co-creators :)

I am confirming our next meet up for Sunday, Nov 1. 

Since we always end up spending many hours together, we decided that would be nice for all of us to bring some snacks to share. So bring something easy to share with the group.

Since it is a Sunday, I want everyone to relax in terms of arriving on time. Just put the intention out there and then just make your way to the meet up without thinking on time. I will just request a direct email from the actual people coming, so we can wait for everyone. There is a purpose in being there earlier or later, the universe is always communicating with us and by being in a relaxed state, we can start tapping into those subtle messages that Abraham talks about. Waiting for others have created a space for people arriving earlier to know each other better and had sparked conversations that brought a lot of answers to all!

Have an amazing week and hope to see you on our next meet up!

Lots of love!

Andrea

results.description:
New York City Marathon is one huge party where the city celebrates the runners, their cheerers and its neighborhoods. There is no reason why it should stop after the race! 

Custom PT has opened their doors to us for a cooldown party from 1-4pm. If you ran the marathon, swing by, perhaps use their ice packs, the recovery boots, and stretch! Or just chat and enjoy some refreshments.

For our after-party, we'll have it right next door at the newly opened 41st St. location of The Stout (http://www.grandcentral.stoutnyc.com/) from 2:30-7pm.  Come celebrate your accomplishment and have a beer. If you cheered for a runner come have several!  We have reserved half of the 2nd floor for cash bar and food service for the entire afternoon.  Just let them know you are there for the Dashing Whippets party.  Please feel free to bring all of your fans and cheerleaders!
results.name: Post Marathon Cooldown at Custom PT & After-Party at The Stout Bar

It's an annual tradition: on the day of the long race (the New York Marathon), poets and audience gather to hear short poems. The members of Brevitas, an online community of over 50 poets, will read their best original poems of the year, books are signed, and literary fun ensues. You can participate in the open mike or just sit back and enjoy the creative works. All poems are 14 lines or less -- so if you don't like something, don't worry -- it won't last long!

TICKETS: $10, available at the door. We will have dinner nearby afterwards (around 5:15 p.m.)

results.description:
Hello F1 Fans,

   After a thrilling race in Austin, Formula 1 heads south of the border for the final double header of the 2015 season Formula 1 season - The Mexican Grand Prix. For the first time in 23 years, Formula One returns to Mexico at the Autodromo Hermanos Rodriguez in Mexico City, named after Mexico’s two most famous drivers: brothers Pedro and Ricardo Rodriguez. 

THE TRACK - The heavily revised track maintains plenty of the character of the original layout. The  Autodromo Hermanos Rodriguez circuit has the highest altitude of any Formula One venue on the calendar affecting both aerodynamics  as well as top speed. The clockwise layout measures 4.438 kms, putting it among the shortest on the calendar with top speed expected to exceed 330kph on the 1.3-km straight.

TYRE ALLOCATION -  With no real data from the track, Pirelli has relied instead on computer simulation to prepare for the race. Pirelli will be bringing the P Zero White medium and Yellow soft tires for Mexico.

TALKING POINTS - Can Perez continue his impressive form of late and make it to the podium at his home race? Will Hamilton extend his dominance this season with another win? Can Williams bounce back and end up on podium in Mexico? 

If you're in the New York City area and looking for some great racing action with other F1 fans, be sure to join us for the Mexican Grand Prix to see who will take the checkered flag. Race will start at 2:00pm EST with the pre-race starting at 1:30pm. In anticipation of a large gathering, Feile will be accepting reservations. Please contact Feile at [masked].

We hope to see you all!
results.name: 2015 Gran Premio de Mexico

results.description:
«La última vez que vi a Miguel Desvern o Deverne fue también la última que lo vio su mujer, Luisa, lo cual no dejó de ser extraño y quizá injusto, ya que ella era eso, su mujer, y yo era en cambio una desconocida...»

Así comienza Los enamoramientos, la nueva novela de Javier Marías, consagrado como uno de los mejores novelistas contemporáneos. María Dolz, la narradora y protagonista, sólo supo su nombre «cuando apareció su foto en el periódico, apuñalado y medio descamisado y a punto de convertirse en un muerto: lo último de lo que se debió de dar cuenta fue de que lo acuchillaban por confusión y sin causa».

Con una prosa profunda y cautivadora, esta novela reflexiona sobre el estado de enamoramiento, considerado casi universalmente como algo positivo e incluso redentor a veces, tanto que parece justificar casi todas las cosas: las acciones nobles y desinteresadas, pero también los mayores desmanes y ruindades.

Los enamoramientos es también un libro sobre la impunidad y sobre la horrible fuerza de los hechos; sobre la inconveniencia de que los muertos pudieran volver, por mucho que se los haya llorado y que en apariencia nada se deseara tanto como su regreso, o al menos que siguieran vivos; también sobre la imposibilidad de saber nunca la verdad cabalmente, ni siquiera la de nuestro pensamiento, oscilante y variable siempre.
results.name: Noviembre - Los enamoramientos - Javier Marías

results.description:
WHERE: New York Society for Ethical Culture, Celebration Hall 
WHEN: 2 PM, every first Sunday 
WHAT: An hour that combines engaging speakers and toe tapping songs. 
WHAT ELSE: Socializing, coffee and cookies after the event

November 1st, Sunday Assembly Celebrates the TRUE MEANING OF THANKSGIVING! We'll have some unusual things going on we're pretty excited about: 

Stone Soup - We'll be making some communal food! Bring your favorite vegetable. We'll put them in a big pot before the Assembly, and then eat it together afterwards. 

The True Story of Thanksgiving - Thanksgiving is a WAY weirder story than you were taught in school. Come learn about the time Squanto threatened to release a bioweapon buried under Plymouth Rock that would bring about the apocalypse. (Seriously. Not joking here) 

And finally... 

Gratitude Open Mic 

We're all here on this beautiful marble together. We've all got some stories about how to find appreciation in life. Gratitude isn't just nice - it's one of few scientifically vetted ways to improve your happiness. 

All this, plus a round of great music to sing together. What more could you want?

results.description:
This is a weekly introductory improv class taught Sundays from 2-4pm.

-- Are you a bit shy and looking to get more comfortable with your public speaking? 

-- Are you a working professional hoping to be a bit more spontaneous during your meetings and interactions with co-workers? 

-- Or are you an actor or improv comedian looking to take your craft to the next level or get more reps?

Then this is the class for you! In this class, you will learn the fundamentals of scene work (role playing). You'll be on your feet quite a bit as I'm believer that you learn (and have more fun) through doing rather than hearing an instructor talk. Brief individual notes will be given, if that's what you're looking for, and tailored to your level of experience. At the end of each class, I'm confident you'll feel a sense of accomplishment that will leave you more energized and excited to tackle the challenges of everyday life, whether at your work place or in your personal life. 

This class is $10.  If money is an issue for you, let me know and we can work something out.  The cost goes to pay for the cost of the room rental, Meetup fees, and website.  

Hope to see you there!


Steve

www.improvnow.com

www.facebook.com/improvnow

Steve Ling is an alumnus of the improv programs of the Upright Citizens Brigade, Peoples Improv Theater, Magnet Theater, & Annoyance Theater. He regularly produces and performs improv, musical improv, & hip hop improv across NYC.

results.description:
Samhain (pronounced SOW-in and Gaelic for “summer’s end”), the Celtic New Year and Day of the Dead for Wiccans and Pagans around the world, is celebrated from sundown October 31-sundown Nov 1. Since we’re meeting on Nov 1, Tamara thought it would be ideal to have a Samhain gathering that day. As many folks know, Samhain is the day when the veil between the worlds is not only its thinnest, but when it is actually lifted. It is a day when we honor our ancestors - both family and magical bloodlines, our loved ones and our pets who have crossed over. And because the veil is so thin, we take a lot of time to communicate with and divine with those who have crossed.

Liz will be giving a brief talk on the history Samhain - as well as some of its modern day traditions. We are too large a group to perform a “dumb supper,” but Liz will describe it from the standpoint of a traditional Wiccan and will also share about mediumship and methods of communicating with the dead (Liz is mainly spiritualist trained, but have been a psychic medium since I was quite young). On Samhain, it is customary to dress up as goddesses, gods and the fae, because the fae are so intensely present during this point of the wheel of the year (the veil is at its thinnest both on Samhain and Beltaine - May 1). Feel free to dress up or just come as you are - witchy-ness and all. Liz will bring down her scrying tools (talking board, black mirror, crystal ball) and cards. Liz thinks it would be awesome to read each other for the New Year and to see what messages come through from the shide (pronounced SHEE uh - or SHEE - meaning the mound or burial mound). God and Goddess bless and see you everyone soon. And Samhain Blessings, in advance, as the veil thins.


 )O(
results.name: Samhain Gathering

results.description:
Free. Manhattan. Sunday, November 1st @ 2:00PM

Gotham Yacht Club is looking for brave-hearted sailors to join us this chilly weekend for the last trip of the season!

We take trips around the Manhattan area in a 50-foot Beneteau. We usually sail the Hudson--the Statue of Liberty to the George Washington Bridge--but also go to Martha's Vineyard, the Hamptons and the Jersey Shore.

We like to fill the boat up with about 20-30 people. No sailing experience is required, but preference is given to experienced sailors since the trips can’t happen without them.  As space is limited on the boat, simply RSVP’ing “Yes” to an event does not guarantee a spot on the boat.  If a spot is available, you will be contacted directly with event details.

Sailors can take their first trip to get acquainted and enjoy the party.  From then on, sailors can choose to (1) work the morning shift and help out with the launch or (2) work the evening shift and help out with the return.  Generally, sailors spend less than a third of the trip working and can take the rest of the time to relax and socialize.

The current crew is made up of young, educated Manhattan professionals. We are looking to meet new people who will enjoy the atmosphere and company of everyone on the boat. 

If you and/or your friends are interested, please copy, paste, and fill out the questionnaire below in an email and send to [masked]. Please include your current email address so that we can contact you directly.  Since boat trips fill up in advance and we receive many applicants, we may not get back to you immediately.  

We look forward to seeing you on the water!

EVERY APPLICANT (REVELERS, SUNBATHERS, ETC.)

Q) Please provide a link to your page on Facebook or other social networking site. Please attach a picture if you don’t have a page on a social networking site.

Q) How old are you?

Q) Where did you attend school?

Q) Will you please tell us a little bit about yourself?

FOR SAILOR APPLICANTS

Q) How many days, lifetime, have you crewed on, but not captained, a sailboat?

Q) How many days, lifetime, have you captained a sailboat?

Q) How many days, lifetime, have you crewed on but not captained, a non-sailboat?

Q) How many days, lifetime, have you captained, a non-sailboat?

Q) Will you tell us a little bit about your sailing experience?


Please copy and paste all questions and answers and send in an email to [masked].

Thank you!


FAQ


Q: Do you have to pay to attend a boat party?


A: No, all boat parties are absolutely free.  You may want to bring food and drinks, which are on a potluck basis.


Q: The specific location is not listed.  Where do we meet for the boat party?


A: Unfortunately, we cannot fit everyone who RSVPs to a MeetUp event onto the boat.  There are some crew members and attendees who are not part of the MeetUp group, so there may be less space than it appears.  In order to avoid miscommunication and needing to leave people on the dock, specific details (including meeting location) are sent to members individually.  Our club's assistant generally does not work after business hours on Friday, so if you have not have received an individual email by then, it's unlikely that you will be able to attend that week’s boat party.


Q: How often are the boat parties?


A: Boat parties are generally every weekend, either on a Saturday or Sunday. They generally last all afternoon into the early evening. 


Q: Do I have to fill out the questionnaire?


A: Yes! Please fill out the questionnaire as thoroughly as possible.  If you are uncomfortable posting any of the information on your profile, please email your responses to [masked].  Without a complete application, you will not be considered to receive an invitation.  The trips last several hours, so we will have 20-30 people in a confined space for an extended period of time. Therefore, we need to have an idea of who we are inviting on the boat and ensure that we have a proper crew.  Please fill out the questionnaire if you are interested in sailing with Gotham Yacht Club.
